下面我依你之前要求的格式（繁體中文、Markdown）整理回覆，幫你鼓勵與導引接下來學習 Python 的語法基礎（變數、運算式、函式、條件區塊），並提供學習策略與簡單練習建議，讓你能更有信心地繼續下一單元（資料型別）。

歡迎回來 — 做得很好！

恭喜你完成第一次評量！能堅持到這裡很棒。剛開始學程式時遇到困難是很正常的——像你說的，程式語言有自己的[語法]，剛學時需要多次練習與[沉浸]才能熟練。接下來我整理一些重點與實作練習，幫助你在下一段學習（資料型別與基礎語法）有紮實的準備。

學習目標（接下來要掌握的基本構件）

  • 變數（variables）：儲存資料的名稱（像語言裡的名詞）。
  • 運算式（expressions）：用變數與運算子組成會產生值的式子（像句子裡的片語）。
  • 函式（functions）：可重複使用的程式區塊（像動詞或子句，完成特定工作）。
  • 條件區塊（if / else）：根據情況選擇不同執行路徑（像[如果…就…否則…]）。

理解並能組合這些元素後，你就能撰寫更有意義的程式。

學習策略（如何有效吸收與應用）

  1. 小步練習、反覆實作
    • 看完一個概念立即寫出 1~3 行程式測試它，並變更輸入觀察結果。
  2. 類比語言學習法（沉浸式學習）
    • 多閱讀範例程式，多模仿與改寫；把程式當作句子練習造句。
  3. 善用互動環境（REPL / Notebook / Colab）
    • 在互動模式或 notebook 實驗，可立即看到輸出並快速除錯。
  4. 分段理解、組合使用
    • 先掌握變數與資料型別，再加入條件與函式，最後合成小程式。
  5. 實作即反思
    • 寫完程式後想一想：輸入、處理、輸出是如何流動的？有沒有更簡潔的方法？

快速練習（立即可在互動環境執行的簡單題）

  1. 變數與輸出
    • 建立兩個變數 a、b，將它們相加並顯示結果。
  2. 條件判斷
    • 寫個小程式判斷數字是否為正數、負數或零，並印出對應訊息。
  3. 函式封裝
    • 寫一個函式 sum(a, b) 回傳兩數和，呼叫它並印出結果。
  4. 綜合題（簡易小任務）
    • 寫函式 classify(x)：若 x > 0 回傳 "positive"，x < 0 回傳 "negative"，否則回傳 "zero"。測試不同輸入。

（若你需要，我可以把上述範例直接寫成可複製執行的 Python 程式碼供你貼到 REPL、Notebook 或 Colab。）

心態提醒（學習程式的過程）

  • 允許自己[多看幾次]：重播教學影片或做題目多次是很正常也很必要的。
  • 錯誤是進步的訊號：每個錯誤都在告訴你哪裡還沒熟悉，逐步修正即可。
  • 練習要有節奏：每天小量但穩定的練習，比一次做太多更有效。

如果你準備好了，我可以立刻幫你做其中一件事：

  • A. 把上面那些[快速練習]直接給出可執行的 Python 範例程式（繁體中文註解），你可以直接貼到 Colab/Notebook/VS Code 執行；
  • B. 幫你規劃接下來一週的練習計畫（每天 20–30 分鐘的題目與重點）；
  • C. 現在開始講解下一個影片內容（資料型別）並給出同時可練習的小範例。

你想要哪一項？

In earlier videos we called out that text written between quotes in Python is called a string. In programing terminology, a string is known as a data type, whether it's a mobile game or a script used to automatically create user accounts. Most programs need to manipulate some kind of data, and that data can come in a lot of different forms, or like we call them, data types. A string is only one kind of data type found in Python. There's a bunch of others, like an integer, which represents whole numbers without a fraction, like 1, and float, which represents real numbers. Or in other words, a number with a fractional part like 2.5. Generally, your computer doesn't know how to mix different data types. For example, adding two integers together makes perfect sense to computers like this. Adding together two strings also makes sense. We just end up with the longer strings that contains the two, like so. But your computer doesn't know how to add an integer and a string. If you tell it to mix these two different data types, your computer isn't going to know what to do and will raise an error. Check it out. Play video starting at :1:11 and follow transcript1:11 No, our first error, but don't panic. Errors are a common part of programming, and you'll probably have to deal with them a lot. The trick is to think of errors as little clues from your computer to help you improve your programing skills. Read the errors carefully, understand what they're telling you, and then use that new knowledge to help you fix the mistake. In this example, the last line of the error message shows us that we've encountered something called a TypeError. When we get a bit of explanatory text that tells us that the plus sign can't be used between an int type and an STR type, which are short names for integer and string. Thinking about what we've already learned about strings, integers, and mixing data types, can you guess what the error is trying to tell us? The message unsupported operand type tells us that we can't add the integer 7 in the string 8 because they're different data types. But what if you didn't have an instructor to helpfully point that out? How would you know? You'd need to use your research skills and the resources we called out earlier in the course to do some investigating. For example, you could look for information about the error by pasting the TypeError message into the search bar of your favorite search engine. This is a common trick used by almost everyone learning to code and even by experienced developers. You'll usually find that other people on the Internet have reported similar errors and solved them Too, back to our example, maybe you're thinking, aren't we adding two numbers here? Looks a bit like it, right? Well, look carefully and remember that anything wrapped in quotation marks is considered a string in Python. So 8 is a string here, while 7 is an integer. To the computer, adding 7 plus 8 is just as strange as adding 7 plus a is to us, and 7 plus a equals no sense at all. It might be helpful to think about data types in terms of information they can represent. For example, the name of a file would be represented as a string data type, while the size of that file might be an integer data type. If you're ever not 100% sure what data type a certain value is, Python gives you a handy way to find out. You can use the type function to have the computer tell you the type. This might come in handy when dealing with code that someone else wrote and you're not sure what data type it's using. For example, pretty neat, right? This tells us that A belongs to str class, which, like we said earlier, is short for string. The number two belongs to the int class, which is short for integer, and 2.5 belongs to the float class. We'll talk more about what we mean by class later in the course. For now, you can just use it as a synonym for data type. So now you know three very common data types in Python. There are plenty of others you'll be using soon, but don't worry about them at the moment. As we continue through the course, we'll come across more data types and learn how to interact with each of them. For now, just remember, mixing your data types will get your computer, well, all mixed up. So keep your strings with your strings, your integers with your integers, and your floats with your floats, and you shouldn't get in too much of a tangle.
gpt-5-mini

下面我根據你提供的內容（繁體中文、Markdown）整理重點與實作範例，幫你理解 Python 的資料型別（特別是 string、int、float）、為何不應混用，以及如何偵測與修正類型錯誤。

Python 的資料型別（重點整理）

  • 字串（string）
    • 以引號包起來的文字，例如 "Hello"、'A'。在 Python 中屬於 str 類別。
  • 整數（integer）
    • 不含小數點的數字，例如 1、7、42。屬於 int 類別。
  • 浮點數（float）
    • 含小數點的數字，例如 2.5、3.14。屬於 float 類別。

電腦在執行運算時會考慮資料型別（type）。某些運算只對相容的型別有意義，例如：

  • int + int → 合理（數學相加）
  • str + str → 合理（字串連接）
  • int + str → 不合理（會產生 TypeError）

常見錯誤（TypeError 範例）與如何閱讀錯誤訊息

範例：執行 7 + "8" 會導致 TypeError，錯誤訊息通常會指出[unsupported operand type(s) for +: 'int' and 'str']。
這表示你試圖用加法運算子把整數（int）和字串（str）混在一起，電腦不清楚你是要做數學加法還是字串連接，因此會拋出錯誤。

處理錯誤的建議步驟：

  1. 讀錯誤訊息，找出哪一行與哪兩個型別發生衝突。
  2. 檢查程式中哪些值是字串、哪些是數字（注意引號）。
  3. 根據需求將值轉型（casting）或改寫程式邏輯。

如何檢查變數的型別

使用 type() 函式可以讓 Python 告訴你某個值或變數的型別。例如：

  • type("A") → <class 'str'>
  • type(2) → <class 'int'>
  • type(2.5) → <class 'float'>

這在處理別人寫的程式或動態取得輸入時特別有用。

常見修正方式：類型轉換（casting）

  • 把字串轉成整數： int("8") → 8
  • 把整數或浮點數轉成字串： str(7) → "7"
  • 把字串轉成浮點數： float("2.5") → 2.5

範例 1（要做數值相加）：

  • 錯誤： 7 + "8" → TypeError
  • 修正： 7 + int("8") → 15

範例 2（要做字串連接）：

  • 錯誤： 7 + "8" → TypeError
  • 修正： str(7) + "8" → "78"

注意：當把字串轉為數字時，字串必須是有效的數字字面值，否則會拋出 ValueError（例如 int("abc") 會失敗）。

小建議與好習慣

  • 清楚區分文字與數字：凡是用引號包的都是字串（"8"、'hello'）。
  • 在接受使用者輸入（input()）時，預設會得到字串，若要數學運算需轉型（例如 int(input())）。
  • 開發時常用 type() 來檢查變數型別，或在除錯時印出變數與其型別。
  • 當看到 TypeError，先不要驚慌，把錯誤訊息當線索一步步追查。

如果你要，我可以：

  • A：提供幾個可直接在 REPL/Notebook/Colab 執行的實際範例程式碼（包含錯誤範例和修正），方便你練習；或
  • B：示範在接受使用者輸入時如何安全地轉型並處理可能的錯誤（含 try/except 範例）。

你想先看哪一個？

In an earlier video, we saw how we can't use the plus operator between an integer and a string because they're different data types. But what happens when we try to operate with an integer and a float instead? Let's find out. Play video starting at ::16 and follow transcript0:16 Woohoo, error free. Python has no problem performing this operation, but what's up with that? Aren't integer and a float two different data types? They sure are, but there's a lot happening under the hood here. Behind the scenes, the computer is busy automatically converting our integer 7 into a float 7. This lets Python then add together the values to return a result that is also a float. We call this process implicit conversion. The interpreter automatically converts one data type into another. We've called this out before, but it's worth highlighting again that Python operations aren't just restricted to numbers. You can also use the plus operator to add together strings. This lets you do things like create sentences from individual words. Just don't forget to add spaces to each word, otherwise the computer will run them all together. So what if you really want to combine a string and a number? Is it possible? It sure is, but only with an explicit conversion. In Python, to convert between one data type and another, we call a function with the name of the type we're converting to. Let's see how this works. Now things are getting a little bit more complex. Let's take a moment to unpack this to make sure it all makes sense. In this script, we're first calculating the area of a triangle, and when printing it, we're adding it to a string. To do this, we need to call the STR function to convert a number into a string. Let's execute it and check out what happens. Play video starting at :1:48 and follow transcript1:48 Our number got converted to a string and printed together with the message. Woohoo, we've learned a little bit about variables, values, expressions and conversions. Next up, we've got a practice quiz to help you solidify your knowledge. As always, take your time and review the content. If you need, you've totally got this. I'll see you in the next video once you're finished.
gpt-5-mini

Good question — let’s explain what happens when you operate on an int and a float in Python, using the video content you provided.

  • Python allows arithmetic between integers and floats without error. For example: 7 + 2.5 evaluates to 9.5.
  • Although int and float are different data types, Python performs an implicit conversion (also called type coercion) behind the scenes: the int is converted to a float, then the operation proceeds. The result of the operation is a float.
  • This implicit conversion applies to numeric operations (addition, subtraction, multiplication, division, etc.) between ints and floats so you normally don’t need to manually convert ints to floats when mixing them.
  • When combining non-compatible types (like int and str), Python raises a TypeError. To combine a number with a string intentionally, you must perform an explicit conversion (casting), e.g. str(3.5) or int("8") (the latter only if the string represents a valid integer).
  • Example summaries you can try in a REPL/Notebook:
    • 7 + 2.5 → 9.5 (type: float)
    • type(7 + 2.5) → <class 'float'>
    • str(7 + 2.5) → "9.5" (now a string, safe to concatenate with other strings)

So: int + float works because Python implicitly converts the int to float and returns a float.

In an earlier video, we saw how we can't use the plus operator between an integer and a string because they're different data types. But what happens when we try to operate with an integer and a float instead? Let's find out. Play video starting at ::16 and follow transcript0:16 Woohoo, error free. Python has no problem performing this operation, but what's up with that? Aren't integer and a float two different data types? They sure are, but there's a lot happening under the hood here. Behind the scenes, the computer is busy automatically converting our integer 7 into a float 7. This lets Python then add together the values to return a result that is also a float. We call this process implicit conversion. The interpreter automatically converts one data type into another. We've called this out before, but it's worth highlighting again that Python operations aren't just restricted to numbers. You can also use the plus operator to add together strings. This lets you do things like create sentences from individual words. Just don't forget to add spaces to each word, otherwise the computer will run them all together. So what if you really want to combine a string and a number? Is it possible? It sure is, but only with an explicit conversion. In Python, to convert between one data type and another, we call a function with the name of the type we're converting to. Let's see how this works. Now things are getting a little bit more complex. Let's take a moment to unpack this to make sure it all makes sense. In this script, we're first calculating the area of a triangle, and when printing it, we're adding it to a string. To do this, we need to call the STR function to convert a number into a string. Let's execute it and check out what happens. Play video starting at :1:48 and follow transcript1:48 Our number got converted to a string and printed together with the message. Woohoo, we've learned a little bit about variables, values, expressions and conversions. Next up, we've got a practice quiz to help you solidify your knowledge. As always, take your time and review the content. If you need, you've totally got this. I'll see you in the next video once you're finished.
請依照之前的回覆方式回答
gpt-5-mini

下面我依你之前要求的格式（繁體中文、Markdown），根據你提供的影片內容整理說明：當 int 與 float 混合運算時 Python 的行為、為什麼會這樣（隱式轉換）、以及如何在需要時用顯式轉換把數字與字串結合。並附上可直接在 REPL/Notebook 執行的範例程式碼與說明。

重點說明

  • int 與 float 混合運算（例如 7 + 2.5）在 Python 中是合法的，執行結果不會產生錯誤。
  • 原因是 Python 會自動做隱式轉換（implicit conversion / type coercion）：把較[低階]的數值型別（int）自動轉成較[高階]的型別（float），然後再執行運算。
  • 混合運算後的結果型別會是 float（例如 7 + 2.5 → 9.5，type 為 float）。
  • 字串（str）與數字（int/float）之間則不會自動混合，直接相加會拋出 TypeError；若要把數字和字串[合併顯示]，必須先做顯式轉換（explicit conversion），例如使用 str() 將數字轉為字串，或使用 f-string / format 等方法將數字嵌入字串中。

範例（可在 REPL / Notebook / Colab 執行）

範例 1：int 與 float 混合運算（隱式轉換）

>>> 7 + 2.5  
9.5  
>>> type(7 + 2.5)  
<class 'float'>

說明：7（int）在運算前會被隱式轉為 7.0（float），結果為 9.5（float）。

範例 2：int 與 str 直接相加會出錯

>>> 7 + "8"  
# TypeError: unsupported operand type(s) for +: 'int' and 'str'

說明：int 與 str 無法直接相加，會得到 TypeError。

範例 3：用顯式轉換把數字與字串結合

# 方法 A：把數字轉成字串  
>>> "The result is: " + str(9.5)  
'The result is: 9.5'  

# 方法 B：使用 f-string（更常用、可讀性較好）  
>>> f"The result is: {9.5}"  
'The result is: 9.5'  

# 方法 C：format  
>>> "The result is: {}".format(9.5)  
'The result is: 9.5'

範例 4：計算三角形面積並與字串一起列印（影片範例）

base = 10  
height = 5  
area = 0.5 * base * height  # 這會是 float（例如 25.0）  
print("The area is: " + str(area))     # 顯式轉換為字串  
# 或使用更推薦的 f-string：  
print(f"The area is: {area}")

小結與建議

  • 對於數值（int / float）混合運算，放心讓 Python 隱式轉換處理；但要注意結果會是 float。
  • 當要把數字和字串合併輸出時，使用顯式轉換（str()）或更常見且安全的 f-string / format。
  • 在處理輸入（例如 input()）時要特別注意，input() 回傳的永遠是字串，若要做數學運算要先用 int() 或 float() 轉型，並處理可能的 ValueError。

如果你要，我可以：

  • A：把上述範例整理成一個小練習檔，包含幾個題目與參考解答；或
  • B：示範在接受使用者輸入時如何安全地轉型並處理例外（含 try/except 範例）。

你要哪一個？

We've seen how we can pass values into a function as parameters by passing values like the name or department in the example earlier. But what about getting values out of a function? This is where the concept of return values comes to play. The work that functions do can produce new results. Sure, we can print the results on the screen, but what if we wanted to use those results later in our script or didn't want to print them at all? We can do this by returning values from the functions we define ourselves. Let's go back to calculating the area of a triangle. Play video starting at ::33 and follow transcript0:33 Do you remember our triangle example from our earlier exercise? The area of the triangle is calculated as base times height divided by 2. Imagine we need to calculate this value several times in our code. It would be useful to have a function that does this for us. Check out how this would look. We use the keyword return to tell Python that this is the return value of a function. When we call the function, we store that value in a variable. Play video starting at ::58 and follow transcript0:58 Let's say we have the two triangles and we want to add up the sum of both areas. Here's what we would do. First, we calculate the two areas separately. Then we add the sum of both areas together. Finally, we print the result, converting it to a string. As you can see in this example, the area triangle function returns a value, which is, not surprisingly the area of the triangle. We store that value in a different variable for each call to the function. Play video starting at :1:41 and follow transcript1:41 In this case, Area A and Area B. Then we operate with those values, adding them into the variable called sum and only printing this final result. This shows the power of the return statement. It allows us to combine calls to functions and to more complex operations, which makes your code more reusable. Return statements in Python are even more interesting because we can use them to return more than one value. Let's say you have a duration of time in seconds, and you want to convert that to the equivalent number of hours, minutes, and seconds. Here's how to do that in Python. Play video starting at :2:17 and follow transcript2:17 Did you spot the new operator in this function? That double slash operator is called floor division. A floor division divides a number and takes the integer part of the division as the result. For example, 5 // 2 is two instead of 2.5. In our example, the first operation is calculating how many hours are in the given amount of seconds, while the second works out how many minutes are left once we subtract the hours and then how many seconds remain after subtracting minutes. We end up with three numbers as a result, so the function returns all three of them. Let's see what this looks like when we're calling a function. Play video starting at :3:10 and follow transcript3:10 Because we know that the function returns three values, we assign the result of the function to three different variables. There's one last thing we should call out about returning values. It is possible to return nothing, and that's perfectly okay. Let's look at an example from an earlier video. Here, the function just printed a message and didn't return anything. What do you think would happen if we try to assign the value of this function to a variable? Let's try it down and see. Play video starting at :3:44 and follow transcript3:44 Here, when we called the function, it printed a message just like we expected. We stored the return value in the result variable, but there was no return statement in the function. The value of result is none. None is a very special data type in Python, used to indicate that things are empty or that they return nothing. That was a lot to learn about functions and the return values. Remember that the key to getting this right is to practice writing the code you just learned as many times as you need. Functions and return values can be tricky concepts to master, but they let us do a bunch of cool stuff. Play video starting at :4:17 and follow transcript4:17 Put the time and effort in to learn it for some really valuable returns.
gpt-5-mini

下面我依你先前指定的格式（繁體中文、Markdown），根據你提供的影片內容整理[函式的回傳（return values）]重點、範例與實務建議，並附上可直接執行的示範程式碼，方便你練習與應用。

函式回傳值（Return values）重點整理

  • 函式可以接受參數（inputs）並執行運算；若要把結果帶回呼叫處，就使用 return 陳述式回傳值。
  • 當呼叫函式時，回傳值可以被指定（assign）給變數，以便後續使用或參與其他運算。
  • 回傳值讓程式更具可重複使用性與模組化：將邏輯封裝在函式裡，呼叫多次並以不同參數取得結果。
  • Python 的 return 可以回傳多個值（實際上回傳一個 tuple），呼叫端可用多個變數接收（tuple unpacking）。
  • 如果函式內沒有 return，預設會回傳 None（表示沒有值），仍可以將其賦值給變數，但該變數會是 None。

影片範例轉成可執行程式碼

示範 1：計算三角形面積並回傳

def area_triangle(base, height):  
    return base * height / 2  

# 呼叫函式並把回傳值存起來  
area_a = area_triangle(10, 5)   # 25.0  
area_b = area_triangle(6, 4)    # 12.0  

total = area_a + area_b  
print("Total area: " + str(total))  # 或使用 f-string： print(f"Total area: {total}")

示範 2：回傳多個值（將秒數轉成 小時、分鐘、秒）

def seconds_to_hms(total_seconds):  
    hours = total_seconds // 3600             # floor division 取整數小時  
    minutes = (total_seconds % 3600) // 60    # 剩下秒數中取整數分鐘  
    seconds = total_seconds % 60              # 剩下秒數  
    return hours, minutes, seconds  # 實際回傳的是一個 tuple  

h, m, s = seconds_to_hms(3675)   # h=1, m=1, s=15  
print(f"{h} hours, {m} minutes, {s} seconds")

示範 3：函式沒有 return → 回傳 None

def say_hello():  
    print("Hello!")  

result = say_hello()   # 印出 Hello!  
print(result)          # 印出 None，因為函式沒有回傳值

額外說明與實務建議

  1. 為何回傳值重要？

    • 讓函式成為[資料處理黑盒]，呼叫端不需知道內部如何計算，只需拿到結果即可繼續處理。
    • 可以把多個小函式串接起來，產生複雜行為但維持程式易讀性。

  2. 回傳多個值時的注意事項：

    • Python 其實回傳一個 tuple，呼叫端可選擇一次接收多個變數或把整個 tuple 指派給一個變數。
    • 範例： vals = seconds_to_hms(100) → vals 為 (0, 1, 40)。

  3. None 的使用：

    • None 表示[沒有值]。常見於函式以副作用（例如印出、寫檔）為目的，並不回傳資料時。
    • 檢查是否有回傳值時可用 if result is None: 來判斷。

  4. 設計建議：

    • 若函式有[重要結果]需被重複使用，應回傳該結果而非直接印出，讓呼叫端決定是否印出或後續處理。
    • 保持函式單一職責：要麼回傳計算結果（pure function），要麼執行副作用（如列印、寫檔），避免同時做太多事，利於測試與重複使用。

如果你願意，我可以：

  • A：把上述範例整理成一個小練習檔（含題目與參考解答），方便你貼到 REPL/Notebook 練習；或
  • B：示範如何把多個小函式串聯起來解一個實際問題（例如：讀入一組三角形尺寸，計算並回傳最大面積、總面積與個別面積清單）。

你要哪一個？

>> As we've called out before, functions are powerful because you can create your own. You can use them to organize the code in your scripts into logical blocks, which makes the code you write easier to use and reuse. Check out this example. This script uses the len function, which returns the length of its string. In this example, the script then uses that length to calculate a number, which we're calling the lucky number here. And finally, it prints a message with the name and the number. Each time we want to perform the calculation, we change the values of the variables and write the formula. Play video starting at ::35 and follow transcript0:35 Then print a greeting followed by the lucky number. See how there are exactly two lines that are the same in the first and second part of the code? When you find code duplication in your scripts, it's a good idea to check if you can clean things up a bit by using a function. How about we rewrite this code, creating a function to group all the duplicated code into just one online? The updated script gives us the exact same result as the original one, but it looks a lot cleaner. First, we've defined a function called lucky number, which carries out our calculation and prints it for us. Then we call the function twice, once with each name. Play video starting at :1:12 and follow transcript1:12 Since we've grouped the calculation and print statements into a function, our code is not only easier to read, but it's also now reusable. We can execute the code inside the lucky number function as many times as we need it by just calling it with a different name so we don't have to write it out again and again for each new name. Does that make sense? Hopefully these examples have helped explain how functions are used and defined, and also demonstrated how useful they can be. Did you notice that we're feeding information into our functions through their parameters? This is one of the many ways that we can input data into our code. The values for those parameters may come from different places, like a file on our computer or through a form on a website, but that doesn't impact our code. Play video starting at :1:54 and follow transcript1:54 The result of the function is still the same, no matter where the parameters come from. Functions are your friends, they can help clean up your code and do math so you don't have to. You'll be using them a lot, both in this course and in your programming life. So get ready to get real friendly with functions.
gpt-5-mini

下面我依你先前要求的格式（繁體中文、Markdown），根據你提供的影片內容整理說明，示範如何把重複程式區塊用函式整理（以[lucky number]範例為核心），並給出可直接執行、容易理解的程式範例與延伸練習建議。

重點概念：用函式消除重複程式碼（DRY — Don't Repeat Yourself）

  • 當你發現程式中有重複的程式行（例如兩次用相同公式計算並列印結果），通常可以把那段重複邏輯抽成一個函式。
  • 函式讓程式更清楚、可重複使用，也方便之後維護與測試。
  • 透過參數把不同的輸入傳入函式，函式負責處理並（視情況）回傳或列印結果。

影片描述的範例說明（文字版）

原始程式：你先以相同公式分別對兩個名字計算[lucky number]，每次都寫同樣的兩行（計算與列印）。
重構後：把計算與列印的程式碼包成一個名為 lucky_number 的函式，接受名字作為參數。呼叫時只要傳入不同的名字即可重複使用相同邏輯。

這樣做的好處：

  • 可讀性更高（主要程式變短，意圖清楚）
  • 若日後計算方式改變，只需在函式內修改一次
  • 更容易在其他地方重複呼叫或測試

建議的 Python 範例程式碼

範例 A：函式直接列印（符合影片的改寫）

def lucky_number(name):  
    length = len(name)  
    number = length * 9  # 範例公式  
    print(f"Hello {name}, your lucky number is {number}")  

lucky_number("Alice")  
lucky_number("Bob")

範例 B：函式回傳值（更通用，呼叫端決定要不要列印）

def lucky_number(name):  
    length = len(name)  
    number = length * 9  
    return number  

# 呼叫端可以自由處理回傳值  
n1 = lucky_number("Alice")  
n2 = lucky_number("Bob")  
print(f"Alice's lucky number is {n1}")  
print(f"Bob's lucky number is {n2}")

範例 C：把輸入來源抽象化（參數可以來自檔案或表單）

def lucky_number(name):  
    return len(name) * 9  

names = ["Alice", "Bob", "Charlie"]     # 這裡可能改成從檔案讀取或表單輸入  
for nm in names:  
    print(f"{nm}: {lucky_number(nm)}")

說明：

  • 示例中用 len(name) 取得字串長度，再套入某個公式（影片以此示範）。實務上可換成任何計算邏輯。
  • 若函式只負責回傳值（範例 B、C），更利於單元測試與重複使用；若你想立即顯示結果，可在函式內列印（範例 A）。

延伸練習（練習題）

  1. 修改 lucky_number 函式，讓計算公式變成： length * 7 + 3。測試幾個名字，觀察結果差異。
  2. 寫一個函式 lucky_message(name, greet=True)：當 greet 為 True 時列印問候與幸運數；否則只回傳數字。
  3. 撰寫一個程式，從一個包含多個名字的檔案（每行一個名字）讀取，對每個名字計算幸運數並把結果寫入另一個檔案。
  4. 將 lucky_number 的邏輯寫成單元測試（例如用 pytest），驗證給定名字回傳的結果是否正確。

如果你要，我可以：

  • A：把上面的三個範例整理成一個完整 Python 檔案，包含註解與可執行的練習題範本；或
  • B：示範如何把函式改寫為回傳值（從列印改為 return），並說明為什麼在大型專案中常偏好回傳值的設計。

你想要哪一個？

>> So far we've looked into how the Python syntax is used for variables, expressions, and defining and using functions. There's a lot more syntax to come, but before we dive into that, let's talk a bit about a different side of programing style on the whole. Having good or bad style when you write code doesn't make much difference between a script succeeding or crashing, but it can make a big difference for the people who use it and contribute to it. Poor programming style can make life difficult for the IT specialists or system administrators who have to read the script after it's written or make changes to it so it works with a new system. Bad style can even give the script's author a headache if it's been a while since they've wrote it. Imagine having to rewrite your own code because it's too messy to understand, yikes. On the flip side, good style can make a script look almost like natural human language. Play video starting at ::51 and follow transcript0:51 It can make the script's intent and construction immediately clear to the reader. Good style makes life easier for people who have to maintain the code and helps them understand what it does and how it does it. It can also reduce errors, since it makes updating the code easier and more straightforward. And most importantly, good style makes you look cool, right? So we agree our code should be stylish. But what makes the style of a piece of code good or bad? Although there are no hard and fast rules that apply to every programming language and situation, keeping a few principles in mind will go a long way to creating good, well styled code. Play video starting at :1:29 and follow transcript1:29 First off, you want your code to be as self documenting as possible. Self-documenting code is written in a way that's readable and doesn't conceal its intent. This principle can be applied to all aspects of writing code, from picking your variable names to writing clear, concise expressions. Take this code snippet for example. It's hard to determine the purpose of this code by just looking at it. The names of the variables don't give the reader much information, and although you can likely work out the result of the calculation, there are no clues to what that result might be used for. In programming lingo, when we rewrite code to be more self documenting, we call this process refactoring. Play video starting at :2:9 and follow transcript2:09 So how would it look if we refactored this code? With this refactored code, the intent should now be more clear. The names of the variables and the function reflect their purpose, which helps the reader understand the code more quickly. You should always aim for your code to be self documenting, but even then, sometimes you may need to Use a particularly tricky bit of code in your script. When good naming and clean organization can't make the code clear, you can add a bit of explanatory text to the code. You do this by adding what we call a comment in Python. Comments are indicated by the hash character. Play video starting at :2:55 and follow transcript2:55 When your computer sees a hash character, it understands that it should ignore everything that comes after that character on that line. Check out how this looks. Using comments lets you explain why a function does something a certain way. It also allows you to leave notes to your future self or other programmers to remind you of what needs to be improved and why. Obviously, it's much easier to read your own code than someone else's, but in my job I work on code that was written by lots of different people, and everybody designs things a little differently. This is why it's so important to comment and document your code well. More often than not, your code will eventually be used by someone other than you. Play video starting at :3:37 and follow transcript3:37 So be a good neighbor. Use a style guide to structure your code in a way that's readable by others or by you in six months, when you've forgotten why you wrote that code in the first place. In upcoming exercises in this course, we'll use comments to let you know what you need to do with the code, and you can always write as many extra comments as you need. Coming up, a quiz to consolidate your newly acquired knowledge about functions. Don't worry, you've got this.
gpt-5-mini

下面依你之前要求的格式（繁體中文、Markdown），根據你提供的內容整理[程式風格（coding style）]重點、具體建議與範例，幫助你把以前學到的變數、運算式與函式知識，套用到寫出更易讀、可維護的程式碼上。

為什麼程式風格重要

  • 好的程式風格不會直接決定程式能否執行，但會大幅影響後續維護與協作者的理解成本。
  • 清楚的程式碼能減少錯誤、加速除錯與功能擴充，也讓你在團隊或回頭看自己程式時少很多頭痛。
  • 壞風格則會讓系統管理員或未來的你不得不重寫或花大量時間釐清邏輯。

主要原則（從影片重點整理）

  1. 讓程式自我說明（self-documenting）

    • 以有意義的變數與函式名稱來表達意圖（例如 total_area 比 a 更直觀）。
    • 讓程式碼讀起來像自然語言，減少閱讀成本。

  2. 消除重複（DRY — Don't Repeat Yourself）

    • 當看到重複程式碼時，考慮用函式把重複邏輯抽出，讓程式更簡潔且易於修改。

  3. 適度加入註解（comments）

    • 註解用來說明[為什麼]這樣做（非只是重複程式碼會做什麼）。
    • 在 Python 中使用 # 做單行註解。
    • 只在必要時加入註解；若程式已自我說明，多餘的註解反而干擾。

  4. 使用風格指南（style guide）

    • 例如 PEP 8（Python 官方風格指南），幫助團隊統一排版與命名規則，使程式在多人維護時更一致易讀。

具體建議與範例

  • 命名

    • 好：student_name, calculate_area, total_price
    • 不好：a, doStuff, x1

  • 把重複邏輯抽成函式（示例）

# 不好（重複）  
name = "Alice"  
length = len(name)  
lucky = length * 9  
print(f"Hello {name}, your lucky number is {lucky}")  

name = "Bob"  
length = len(name)  
lucky = length * 9  
print(f"Hello {name}, your lucky number is {lucky}")  

# 好（抽成函式、可重用）  
def lucky_number(name):  
    """回傳給定名字的幸運數（示範公式：len*9）"""  
    return len(name) * 9  

for nm in ["Alice", "Bob"]:  
    print(f"Hello {nm}, your lucky number is {lucky_number(nm)}")
  • 註解用途範例
def seconds_to_hms(total_seconds):  
    # 使用整數除法計算整小時數  
    hours = total_seconds // 3600  
    # 先取出剩餘秒數，再計算整分鐘  
    minutes = (total_seconds % 3600) // 60  
    seconds = total_seconds % 60  
    return hours, minutes, seconds

註解說明[為什麼]與[關鍵步驟]，而非逐字重複程式碼內容。

  • 盡量讓函式回傳有用的值（不要只印出）
    • 回傳值讓呼叫端決定要如何使用結果（列印、儲存或再處理），也有助於單元測試。

小檢查清單（提交或回顧程式前自我檢查）

  • 變數與函式名稱是否有描述性？
  • 是否有重複程式碼可以抽成函式？
  • 註解是否說明[為什麼]而非[做什麼]？
  • 是否符合團隊或專案的風格指南（例如 PEP 8）？
  • 函式是否單一職責（只做一件事）且容易測試？

如果你想，我可以：

  • A：依 PEP 8 幫你檢查一段程式（你貼程式碼給我），並提供具體改寫建議；或
  • B：把這些原則整理成一份簡短的檢查表（可複製貼到 README 或提交說明中）。

你要哪一個？

We've seen a few arithmetic expressions so far like addition, subtraction, and division. Remember, when we turn Python into a calculator? Well, Python can also compare values. This lets us check whether something is smaller than, equal to, or bigger than something else. This allows us to take the result of our expressions and use them to make decisions. Check out these three examples. In the first example, 10 is greater than one, so the value true is printed as a result. Play video starting at ::29 and follow transcript0:29 True is a value that belongs to another data type called the Boolean. Booleans represent one of two possible states, either true or false. Every time you compare things in Python, the result is a Boolean of the appropriate value. In the second example, we can see our very first equality operator, which is formed by putting two equal signs together. We use this operator to test whether two things are equal to each other. In this example, the string cat is not equal to the string dog, so the Boolean that's printed is false. In our third example, we're doing the opposite comparison. Play video starting at :1:6 and follow transcript1:06 By pairing an exclamation mark and an equals sign, we're using the not equals operator, which is the negated form of the equality operator. In this particular line of code, the operator checks that one isn't equal to two. We called out before that the plus operator doesn't work between integers and strings. What do you think will happen if we try to compare an integer and a string? Let's find out by seeing if the number one is smaller than the string 1. We get a type error. That's the same error we got before. Play video starting at :1:43 and follow transcript1:43 This happens because Python doesn't know how to check if a number is smaller than a string. What about the equality operator? In this case, the interpreter has no problem telling us that the integer 1 and the string 1 aren't the same. What gives? Basically, although they may seem similar to us because they both contain the same number, it's clear to the computer that one is a number and the other is a string. For the computer, it's obvious that they are completely different entities. On top of the comparison and equality operators, Python also has a set of logical operators. Play video starting at :2:26 and follow transcript2:26 These operators allow you to connect multiple statements together and perform more complex comparisons. In Python, the logical operators are the words and, or, and not. Let's look at some examples. To evaluate as true, the and operator would need both expressions to be true at the same time. Here, we're comparing strings, and the bigger and smaller operators refer to alphabetical order. Yellow comes after cyan, but brown doesn't come after magenta. This means that the first statement is true, but the second one isn't, which makes the result of the whole expression false. Play video starting at :3:13 and follow transcript3:13 If we use the or operator instead, the expression will be true if either of the expressions are true and false only when both expressions are false. Let's try it out. Twenty five is definitely not bigger than 50, but one is different than two. In the end, the whole expression is true. Last up, the not operator inverts the value of the expression that's in front of it. If the expression is true, it becomes false. If it's false, it becomes true, just like this. Play video starting at :3:44 and follow transcript3:44 Logical operators are important because they help us write more complex expressions. We'll see this in action in the next few videos. If this is the first time you've come across these operators, it might seem like there's a lot to remember. But don't worry, you'll learn most of them very quickly just by practicing. In the next reading, we have a cheat sheet that lists all the operators available and what each one does. It's a handy resource you're sure to find useful when writing your own scripts.
gpt-5-mini

下面以你提供的影片內容（繁體中文、Markdown）整理比較運算、布林（Boolean）與邏輯運算子的重點、行為與範例，方便你快速理解並在練習時套用。

比較運算（Comparison operators）

  • 比較運算會傳回布林值（Boolean）：True 或 False。
  • 常用比較運算子：
    • 大於：>
    • 小於：<
    • 大於等於：>=
    • 小於等於：<=
    • 等於（相等）：==
    • 不等於：!=

範例：

>>> 10 > 1  
True  

>>> "cat" == "dog"  
False  

>>> 1 == "1"  
False    # 因為 int 與 str 類型不同

注意：

  • 某些比較（如大小比較 <, >）在不同資料型別之間會發生 TypeError，例如試圖比較整數與字串：
>>> 1 < "1"  
# TypeError: '<' not supported between instances of 'int' and 'str'
  • 等於運算（==）可以比較不同型別並回傳 False（而不是拋錯），因為型別不同代表不相等。

布林（Boolean）

  • 布林是只有兩個可能值的資料型別：True 或 False。
  • 每次比較運算都會回傳布林，用來在條件判斷（if/while）或邏輯運算中決定程式流程。

邏輯運算子（Logical operators）

  • 用於連接多個布林表達式，產生更複雜的條件判斷：
    • 且（and）：只有當左右兩邊都為 True 時，整體才為 True。
    • 或（or）：只要左右任一為 True，整體即為 True（只有兩邊都為 False 時才為 False）。
    • 非（not）：反轉布林值，True → False，False → True。

範例與說明：

# and：兩邊都要為 True  
>>> ("yellow" > "cyan") and ("brown" > "magenta")  
# 比較字串大小是依字母序（alphabetical order）  
# "yellow" 比 "cyan" 晚（True），但 "brown" 並不晚於 "magenta"（False）  
# 因此整體為 False  

# or：任一為 True 即為 True  
>>> (25 > 50) or (1 != 2)  
# 25 > 50 為 False，1 != 2 為 True，整體為 True  

# not：反轉結果  
>>> not (1 == 1)  
False

補充：

  • 字串的大小比較是依字母序（例如 "a" < "b"）。比較時要留意大小寫會影響排序（大寫與小寫的字元碼不同）。
  • 邏輯運算子也可用於更複雜的條件組合，例如 (a > b) and ((c == d) or not e)。

實務建議與練習

  • 練習不同型別間的比較，觀察哪些會拋出 TypeError（如 int 與 str 的大小比較）。
  • 用比較與邏輯運算來撰寫 if 判斷，並在程式中印出中間結果以理解運算順序與短路行為（and / or 具短路特性）。
  • 注意字串比較與數字比較的差異，必要時先做型別轉換（例如將輸入的字串轉為整數再比較）。

如果你想，我可以：

  • A：把上面範例整理成一個小練習檔（含題目與參考解答）；或
  • B：示範幾個常見錯誤情境（例如比較 int 與 str、字串大小寫問題）並給出修正方式。

你要哪一個？

Now that we're armed with knowledge of Python's expressions, comparatives, and variables, we can dive right into how to use them in our scripts to perform different actions based on their values. The ability of a program to alter its execution sequence is called branching, and it's a key component in making your scripts useful. You probably use the idea of branding a bunch in your everyday life. For example, if it's before noon, you might greet someone by saying good morning instead of good afternoon or good evening. If it's raining outside, you might choose to take an umbrella. If it's cold, you probably wear a jacket. In your scripts, you can instruct your computer to make decisions based on inputs, too. Play video starting at ::38 and follow transcript0:38 Let's take a look at an IT focused example. In many companies, new employees can choose the user name they'll use to access the company's systems, and usually the chosen user name needs to fit with a given set of guidelines. Companies can set different criteria for what a valid username looks like. For now, let's assume that at your company, a valid username has to have at least three characters. You've been tasked with writing a program that will tell the user if their choice is valid or not. To do that, you could write a function like this. This function checks whether the length of the user name is smaller than three. Play video starting at :1:14 and follow transcript1:14 If it is, the function prints a message saying that the username is invalid. Look closely at how the if statement is written. We write the keyword if followed by the condition that we want to check for and then followed by a colon. After that comes the body of the if block, which is indented further to the right. You may notice that there are some similarities between how an if block and a function are defined. The keyword, either def or if indicates the start of a special block. At the end of the first line, we use a colon, and then the body of the function or the if block is indent to the right. Play video starting at :1:52 and follow transcript1:52 But there's also an important difference between how an if block and a function are defined. The body of the if block will only execute when the condition evaluates to true. Otherwise, it's skipped. Of course, you can do a lot more things inside the body of the if block than just printing stuff. As we expand our programming abilities, we'll learn how to do things like shorten text that's too long, delete a file if it exists, start a service if it's not running, and a bunch more. If your code is inside a function, you could also choose to return a value depending on whether a certain condition is met. Can you imagine how that would look? Play video starting at :2:29 and follow transcript2:29 By now, you know how to define functions, and inside those functions, you can now make your program do something only when certain conditions are met. Ready to branch out and make our branches even more interesting with else statements. Then hop on over to the next video, or else you'll miss out.
gpt-5-mini

下面依你先前要求的格式（繁體中文、Markdown），根據你提供的影片內容整理[條件判斷（branching / if）]的重點、語法與範例，並補充實務建議與練習題，方便你把比較運算、變數與函式應用在實際決策流程中。

條件分支（Branching）重點

  • 分支讓程式根據條件改變執行流程，是撰寫有用腳本的關鍵。
  • 常見應用場景：根據時間問候（早安/午安）、根據天氣帶傘、驗證使用者輸入（如使用者名稱長度）、檔案存在性檢查與服務狀態處理等。
  • Python 使用 if、elif、else 關鍵字來建立分支。if 後接條件表達式和冒號，接著縮排撰寫在條件成立時要執行的程式區塊。

if 語法範例與說明

基本形式：

if 條件:  
    # 條件為 True 時執行的區塊（需縮排）

帶 else 的範例（影片的使用者名稱驗證）：

def validate_username(name):  
    if len(name) < 3:  
        print("Invalid username: must be at least 3 characters")  
    else:  
        print("Username is valid")  

validate_username("Al")    # Invalid username...  
validate_username("Amy")   # Username is valid

說明：

  • if 後的條件會被評估為布林（Boolean）。若為 True，執行對應縮排的區塊；否則跳過該區塊。
  • else 是在 if 條件不成立時要執行的替代區塊（選用）。

使用 elif（多條件分支）：

def greet_by_hour(hour):  
    if hour < 12:  
        print("Good morning")  
    elif hour < 18:  
        print("Good afternoon")  
    else:  
        print("Good evening")

在函式內根據條件回傳值：

def is_valid_username(name):  
    return len(name) >= 3  

if is_valid_username("Bob"):  
    print("OK")  
else:  
    print("Too short")

建議盡量讓函式回傳值，由呼叫端決定要不要列印，這樣更通用也利於測試。

常見注意事項與實務建議

  • 縮排很重要：Python 用縮排分辨程式區塊，混用空格與 Tab 會造成問題（遵循 PEP 8 建議使用 4 個空格作為縮排）。
  • 條件中可使用比較運算與邏輯運算子（and/or/not）來組合複雜條件。
  • 避免在 if 區塊中寫太多事，保持單一職責（例如判斷放在函式內，執行動作由呼叫端處理）。
  • 對使用者輸入或外部資料做驗證時，除了檢查長度，也應考慮是否包含非法字元、是否需要正規化（如去除前後空白）或型別轉換的錯誤處理。
  • 在需要處理多種錯誤情況時，使用明確且容易理解的錯誤訊息，幫助使用者與後續維護者。

延伸練習題（建議自行實作）

  1. 寫一個函式 validate_username(name)，除了檢查長度（>=3）外，還要確保只包含英文字母與數字（isalnum）。若不合格，回傳不同的錯誤訊息。
  2. 寫一個函式 suggest_username(name)：若 name 太短或包含非法字元，自動回傳一個建議的合法使用者名稱（例如 name 去掉非法字元並補上數字）。
  3. 寫一個小程式，讀取使用者輸入的時刻（0–23），並根據 hour 印出適當的問候（早安/午安/晚安）。處理無效輸入（非整數或超出範圍）。
  4. 將 validate_username 與檔案操作結合：從檔案讀多個候選使用者名稱，驗證每一個並把合法與不合法的分別寫入兩個檔案。

如果你要，我可以：

  • A：幫你實作練習題 1–2 的參考解答；或
  • B：示範如何把使用者輸入（input()）與錯誤處理（try/except）結合，以安全地取得數字時間並進行分支判斷。

你想看哪一個？

>> The if statement is already a pretty useful construct, but we can extend it to make it even more powerful. Think about the username example from the last video. What if we also wanted to print a message when the username was valid? Here we've included an else statement to achieve this. The program can now go in one of two directions, depending on the length of the username. If it's not long enough, we get a message indicating that the username is invalid. But if the program verifies that the username is long enough, it will print a message saying it is valid. Play video starting at ::34 and follow transcript0:34 Pay attention to how the else statement is written. It uses the else keyword followed by a colon to indicate the beginning of the else block. Once again, the body of the block is further indented to the right. As we've called out before, these blocks can contain multiple lines and do more than just print messages. They can do calculations, modify values, return values, and a lot more. And remember that you can choose to use as many or as few spaces as you want for the indentation, but you always need to indent, and you always need to use the same number of spaces. The else statement is very useful, but we don't always need it. Play video starting at :1:12 and follow transcript1:12 Say we want to have a function that checks if a value is even or odd. We could do that with a piece of code like this. Here we're using a new operator, so let's first explain that the modulo operator is represented by the percentage sign and returns the remainder of the integer division between two numbers. The integer division is an operation between integers that yields two results, which are both integers, the quotient and the remainder. So if we do an integer division between 5 and 2, the quotient is 2 and the remainder is 1. If we do an integer division between 11 and 3, the quotient is and the remainder is 2. Even numbers are all multiples of 2, which means the remainder of the integer division between an even number and two is always going to be zero. Play video starting at :1:59 and follow transcript1:59 In this function, we're using this principle to decide whether a number is even or not. So how come we have these two return statements, one below the other, without an else statement? The trick is that when a return statement is executed, the function exits so that the code that follows doesn't get executed. This means that if the number is even, the computer will reach the return true statement and exit the function. Anything that comes after that will only be executed if the condition in the if statement was false. In other words, once the function reaches the return false line, we know for sure that the if condition was false, which means the number was odd at first. You might feel more comfortable including the else statement, even if it's not needed, and that's totally okay. Play video starting at :2:45 and follow transcript2:45 It's important to know that both ways of writing this are correct, and remember that this technique can only be used when you're returning a value inside the if-statement. To recap, the if statement allows us to branch the execution based on a specific condition being true. The else statement lets us set a piece of code to run only when the condition of the if-statement was false. If you return a value inside an if-block, then the code after the block will only be executed if the condition was false, all makes sense. If all these ifs and elses are starting to get a little confusing, that's okay. There's a lot to soak up here, and the best way to do that is. Yeah, you guessed it, practice. Play video starting at :3:25 and follow transcript3:25 So review the content and practice on your own as much as you need. Once you're done, meet me over in the next video.
gpt-5-mini

下面依你先前要求的格式（繁體中文、Markdown），整理影片中關於 if / else、return 與 modulo（取餘數）運算的重點、範例與習作建議，幫你快速掌握這些控制流程技巧。

重點摘要：if / else、return 與 modulo

  • if/else 讓程式在條件為真或為假時分別執行不同區塊：
    • if 條件成立 → 執行 if 區塊
    • 否則 → 執行 else 區塊（若有的話）
  • else 的語法：使用 else 關鍵字後接冒號，接續縮排的區塊。
  • 縮排必須一致（PEP 8 建議使用 4 個空格）；Python 以縮排界定區塊。
  • return 在函式內執行時會立即結束函式並回傳值；因此若在 if 內 return，之後的程式只會在該條件為 False 時才執行（可用來省略 else）。
  • modulo（%）運算子會回傳兩數相除的餘數：若 n % 2 == 0，代表 n 為偶數；否則為奇數。

範例程式碼

  1. if / else 範例（使用者名稱檢查）
def validate_username(name):  
    if len(name) < 3:  
        print("Invalid username: must be at least 3 characters")  
    else:  
        print("Username is valid")
  1. 使用 modulo 判斷偶數與奇數（兩種寫法：有 else 與省略 else）
# 含 else 的寫法  
def is_even(n):  
    if n % 2 == 0:  
        return True  
    else:  
        return False  

# 省略 else（等價）  
def is_even(n):  
    if n % 2 == 0:  
        return True  
    return False

說明：兩種寫法功能相同；當 if 內 return 被執行時，函式結束，後面的程式只會在 if 條件為 False 時執行，因此 else 可選但非必要。

  1. 實用寫法（更簡潔）：
def is_even(n):  
    return n % 2 == 0

說明：條件表達式本身就是布林值，直接回傳即可。

實務建議

  • 若 if 區塊內是 return，且後續只處理[否]的情況，省略 else 可使程式更扁平、易讀。
  • 但若省略 else 會造成邏輯不清或較難閱讀，也可以保留 else，維持清楚的控制流程。選擇取決於團隊風格與可讀性考量。
  • 使用 descriptive（具描述性）的函式與變數名稱，讓 if / else 的意圖更清楚。
  • 在處理使用者輸入時，先做資料清理（如 strip()）與驗證，避免意外的邊界情況。

練習題（建議實作）

  1. 實作 is_even，並以 0、1、2、-3、10 測試結果。
  2. 寫一個函式 classify_number(n)，回傳字串 "even" 或 "odd"（練習回傳字串而非布林）。
  3. 寫一個 validate_username_advanced(name)：
    • 長度至少 3，且只允許英數字（isalnum）。
    • 若合法回傳 True，否則回傳 False 並提供簡短理由（例如回傳 ("error", "too short") 與 ("error", "invalid chars")）。
  4. 比較兩種風格：用 else 與不使用 else 的 is_even，閱讀並寫下你偏好哪一種，並解釋理由。

需要我幫你做哪一項？

  • A：直接給出練習題 1–3 的參考解答程式碼；或
  • B：把上述內容整理成一個可執行的 Python 範例檔，包含測試輸出與說明註解。
The if and else blocks allow us to branch execution depending on whether a condition is true or false. But what if there are more conditions to take into account? This is where the elif statement, which is short for else if comes into play. But before we jump into how to use it, let's take a look at why we need it in the first place. Let's go back to our trusty user name validation example. Now, what if your company also had a rule that usernames longer than 15 characters aren't allowed? How could we let the user know if their chosen username was too long? Play video starting at ::34 and follow transcript0:34 We could do it like this. In this case, we're adding an extra if block inside the else block. This works, but the way the code is nested makes it hard to read. To avoid unnecessary nesting and make the code clearer, Python gives us the elif keyword, which lets us handle more than two comparison cases. Take a look. The elif statement looks very similar to the I statement. It's followed by a condition and a colon and a block of code indented to the right that forms the body. Play video starting at :1:4 and follow transcript1:04 The condition must be true for the body of the F block to be executed. The main difference between elif and if statements is we can only write an elif block as a companion to an I block. That's because the condition of the elif statement will only be checked if the condition of the if statement wasn't true. So in this example, the program first checks whether the username is less than three characters long and prints a message if that's the case. If the username has at least three characters, the program then checks if it's longer than 15 characters. If it is, we get a message to tell us that. Finally, if none of the above conditions were met, the program prints a message indicating that the username is valid. Play video starting at :1:46 and follow transcript1:46 There's no limit to how many conditions we can add, and it's easy to include new ones. For example, say the company decided that the username shouldn't include numbers. We could easily add an extra elif condition to check for this. Cool. You now know how to compare things and use those comparisons for your if, elif, and else statements, and you are using all of them inside functions. Using branching to determine your program's flow opens up a whole new realm of possibilities in your scripts. You can use comparisons to pick between executing different pieces of code, which makes your script pretty flexible. Play video starting at :2:20 and follow transcript2:20 Branching also helps you do all kinds of practical things like only backing up files with a certain extension or only allowing log and access to a server during certain times of the day. Anytime your program needs to make a decision, you can specify its behavior with a branching statement. Are you starting to notice tasks in your day to day that could be made more efficient with scripting? There's so many possibilities, and we're only just getting started with all the cool stuff programming can help you do. Wow, we've covered a lot in these last few videos. Remembering all these concepts can take some time, and the best way to learn them is to use them. We've put together a cheat sheet for you in the next reading. Play video starting at :2:58 and follow transcript2:58 You'll find all these operators and branching blocks listed there in one handy resource. It's super useful when you need a quick refresher, so no skipping the reading.
gpt-5-mini

下面以你先前要求的格式（繁體中文、Markdown），將影片內容整理成關於 if / elif / else 的重點、用法範例、常見陷阱與練習題，方便你快速理解並應用多分支判斷。

為什麼需要 elif？

  • if/else 只能處理兩種情況（條件成立或不成立）。當有多個互斥或分層的條件需要處理時，過度巢狀的 if 會讓程式難讀。
  • elif（else if 的縮寫）可以串接在 if 與 else 之間，避免不必要的巢狀，讓多分支邏輯更清楚。

if / elif / else 的行為與規則

  • if 會先檢查其條件；若為 True，執行該區塊並跳過後面的 elif/else。
  • 若 if 為 False，程式依序檢查每個 elif 的條件，第一個為 True 的 elif 其區塊會被執行，其後的 elif 與 else 都會被跳過。
  • 若所有 if/elif 都為 False，則執行 else（若存在）。
  • 可以有任意數量的 elif（包含 0 個）。
  • elif 只能跟在 if 或其他 elif 後面；不能單獨使用。

範例：多重使用者名稱驗證

需求：使用者名稱長度至少 3 字元，且不能超過 15 字元；否則分類提示。

def validate_username(name):  
    if len(name) < 3:  
        print("Invalid: username must be at least 3 characters")  
    elif len(name) > 15:  
        print("Invalid: username must be at most 15 characters")  
    else:  
        print("Username is valid")

延伸：若公司還不允許數字，可以新增 elif：

def validate_username(name):  
    if len(name) < 3:  
        print("Invalid: too short")  
    elif len(name) > 15:  
        print("Invalid: too long")  
    elif any(char.isdigit() for char in name):  
        print("Invalid: no digits allowed")  
    else:  
        print("Username is valid")

說明：

  • 條件依序檢查，第一個符合的分支執行後其餘分支不會再被檢查，這對於互斥條件很有用。
  • 使用簡潔、可讀的條件與說明文字能讓維護者或使用者更快理解回饋原因。

常見陷阱與提醒

  • 巢狀 if 雖然可以達成，但會降低可讀性，優先考慮用 elif 改寫。
  • 條件順序很重要：把互斥或較具體的條件放前面，避免被較寬鬆的條件先捕獲。
  • 若某個分支在執行後需要結束函式（例如 return），可以省略 else，利用 return 的提前結束來讓邏輯更扁平。但在多重 elif 中仍可使用 return；注意可讀性。
  • 若使用 multiple checks（例如同時檢查長度與字元類型），可用多個條件或把檢查拆成幾個函式，提高可測試性。

練習題（建議實作）

  1. 實作 validate_username(name)：條件如下
    • 長度 < 3 → "too short"
    • 長度 > 15 → "too long"
    • 含數字 → "no digits allowed"
    • 含非法字元（非英數字與底線）→ "invalid characters"
    • 否則 → "valid"
  2. 寫一個函式 grade(score)：依分數回傳等級
    • score >= 90 → "A"
    • 80–89 → "B"
    • 70–79 → "C"
    • 60–69 → "D"
    • < 60 → "F"
      使用 elif 串接實作。
  3. 比較兩種風格：在含多個 return 的情況下，用或不用 else；示範各自的程式並寫出何時偏好哪種寫法（理由）。

如果你要，我可以：

  • A：直接寫出練習題 1 與 2 的參考解答程式碼（含註解與測試輸出）；或
  • B：把第二個延伸範例（不允許數字）改寫成回傳錯誤碼與訊息的版本，方便程序化處理與測試（例如回傳 (False, "too short") 或 (True, "")）。

你想看哪一個？

First off, we're going to talk about while loops. While loops instruct your computer to continuously execute your code based on the value of a condition. This works in a similar way to branching if statements. The difference here is that the body of the block can be executed multiple times instead of just once. Check out this program. Can you guess what it does? Before we execute it to find out, let's go through it together line by line. Play video starting at ::26 and follow transcript0:26 In the first line, we're assigning the value of zero to the variable x. We call this action initializing, to give an initial value to a variable. In the line after that, we're starting the while loop. We're setting a condition for this loop that x needs to be smaller than five. Right now, we know that x is 0 since we've just initialized it, so this condition is currently true. On the next two lines, we have a block that's indented to the right. Here, we can use what we learned about functions and conditionals to identify that this is the while loop's body. Play video starting at :1: and follow transcript1:00 There are two lines in the body of the loop. In the first line, we print a message followed by the current value of x. In the second line, we increment the value of x. We do this by adding one to its current value and assigning it back to x. After the first execution of the body of the loop, x will be 1 instead of 0. Because this is a loop, the computer doesn't just continue executing with the next line in the script. Instead, it loops back around to re-evaluate the condition for the while loop. Play video starting at :1:33 and follow transcript1:33 Because one here is still smaller than five, it executes the body of the loop again. It then prints the message and once more increments x by one. The x is now 2. The computer will keep doing this until the condition isn't true anymore. In this example, the condition will be false when x is no longer smaller than 5. Once the condition is false, the loop finishes and the next line is executed. Finally, the last line of our code prints the last value of x. Play video starting at :2:5 and follow transcript2:05 Now that this code makes a bit more sense, what do you think will happen when we execute it? Ready to find out? Let's execute the code and see what happens. We had five lines with a message not there yet and then at the end of the script, the value of x was 5. This was a simple example of how a while loop behaves. As we've said before, we're learning the building blocks of programming. Once you know those building blocks, you can combine them to create more complex expressions. Play video starting at :2:41 and follow transcript2:41 As an IT specialist, while loops can be super helpful. You can use them to keep asking for a username if the one provided isn't valid or maybe try an operation until it succeeds. Knowing how to construct these expressions can help you get your computer to do a whole lot with only a little bit of code. It's pretty powerful stuff we're learning here. Now that you've got an idea of how a while loop works, let's spice it up with another example.
gpt-5-mini

下面以繁體中文、Markdown 格式整理 while 迴圈的重點、語法、範例與常見陷阱，並附上幾個實作練習與應用情境，幫你快速掌握重複執行的邏輯。

while 迴圈重點

  • while 迴圈會反覆執行其區塊（body），只要條件為 True 就持續執行。
  • 與 if 的差別在於：if 只在條件為真時執行一次；while 會重複執行直到條件變為 False。
  • 必須注意循環變數（loop variable）的初始化與在迴圈內更新，否則可能造成無限迴圈（infinite loop）。

基本語法

x = 0              # 初始化  
while x < 5:       # 條件為 True 時執行迴圈主體  
    print("x is", x)  
    x = x + 1      # 更新循環變數，避免無限迴圈  
# 迴圈結束後會繼續執行下面的程式  
print("Final x:", x)

執行結果會印出 x 的值從 0 到 4，最後 "Final x: 5"。

範例說明（以影片範例解釋）

  • 先將 x 設為 0（初始化）。
  • while 條件 x < 5 初始為 True，執行迴圈內的 print 與 x 增量 x = x + 1。
  • 每次迴圈結束會回到 while 再次檢查條件，直到 x 不再小於 5（也就是 x==5）時結束迴圈。
  • 迴圈結束後，接著執行後面的程式（例如印出最終的 x）。

常見用途（IT 專業應用）

  • 反覆向使用者詢問輸入直到驗證成功（例如使用者名稱或密碼）。
  • 當某個外部操作尚未成功時持續重試（搭配等待/超時邏輯）。
  • 讀取資料來源直到結束（雖然對於檔案或串流通常用 for 或專用函式更常見）。
  • 實作簡單的監控循環（例如定期檢查服務狀態，注意加入 sleep 與退出條件）。

注意事項與陷阱

  • 避免無限迴圈：確認在迴圈內會有改變條件的操作（例如更新變數、break、或在某條件下 return）。
  • 若迴圈依賴外部事件或輸入，建議實作明確的超時或最大重試次數，避免程式卡死。
  • 在需要等待的循環中（例如輪詢某服務），應加入短暫等待（time.sleep）以降低 CPU 使用與網路壓力。
  • 若迴圈體過長或複雜，考慮把邏輯拆成函式，提高可讀性與可測試性。

進階技巧

  • 使用 break 提前離開迴圈：
while True:  
    data = get_input()  
    if data == "quit":  
        break  
    process(data)
  • 使用 continue 跳過本次迴圈剩餘程式，直接進入下一輪：
i = 0  
while i < 10:  
    i += 1  
    if i % 2 == 0:  
        continue   # 偶數時跳過下面的 print  
    print(i)      # 只印出奇數

練習題（建議實作）

  1. 寫一個程式不斷要求使用者輸入使用者名稱（input()），直到 validate_username(name) 回傳 True（可重用前面做的驗證函式）。
  2. 寫一個倒數器函式 countdown(n)，使用 while 迴圈每秒印出剩餘秒數，最後印 "Liftoff!"（提示：使用 time.sleep(1)）。
  3. 實作一個重試機制 retry(operation, max_attempts)：當 operation() 拋出例外時重試，最多重試 max_attempts 次，若成功回傳結果，否則回傳 None 或拋出例外。
  4. 實作一個求質數的簡單算法：從 2 開始檢查每個數是否為質數並印出前 N 個質數（使用 while 控制外層計數）。

需要我幫你做哪一個？

  • A：把練習題 1 或 2 的參考答案寫出來（含說明與測試示例）；或
  • B：示範 retry 範例（包含例外處理與最大重試次數）並說明實務上如何加上指數退避（exponential backoff）。
In the last video, we saw a very simple example of a while loop. We looked at a basic syntax of the loop and how it works. Let's now apply this knowledge to a similar example, but this time with a while loop inside a function. Can you work out what this function does? In this example, we start out by initializing a variable called x. In this case, we initialize it with the value of one. Then we enter our while loop, which checks to see if the value inside of the X variable is less than the parameter N that the function received. Play video starting at ::34 and follow transcript0:34 If that comparison evaluates to true, then the code inside the while block is executed. Say we Pass a value of 5 as a parameter to this function. In the first pass through the loop, X is always equal to 1, so the comparison 1 smaller than or equal to 5 would be true. And we then enter the body of the loop. In the body, we first print a message indicating that the current attempt number. And then we increase the value of x by 1 to increment the number. We're using a slightly different expression than before x + = 1 is a shorthand version of x equals x +1. Play video starting at :1:15 and follow transcript1:15 You can use either expression since they both mean the same thing. The process continues until the result of the comparison isn't true anymore, which happens when X is bigger than n. In our current example, this would be when the value of x is 6. Let's see it in action. In these past examples, we've used the simple conditions of a number being smaller or smaller or equal than another number. These are common conditions, but they're by no means the only conditions you can have in a while loop. It's common, for example, to call a separate function that evaluates the condition like this. Play video starting at :1:52 and follow transcript1:52 In this case, there's a lot of code hidden behind functions, and it's doing stuff we don't see. There's a getusername function that asks the user for a username and a valid username function that validates that username. And all this is happening in just a handful of characters. As you can see, you can pack a lot of punch into just a short line of code. In this case, the body of the while loop will be executed until the user enters a valid username. The important thing to remember is that the condition used by the while loop needs to evaluate to true or false. It doesn't matter if this is done by using comparison operators or calling additional functions. Play video starting at :2:33 and follow transcript2:33 The conditions used in while loops can also become more complex if we use the logical operators that we encountered when looking into branching and or and not. This lets us combine the values of several expressions to get the result we want. Okay, we've now covered what a While loop is and learned its syntax and basic behavior. Some of this stuff can be a bit tricky, and you're doing great. Keep sticking with it. Next, we're going to do a rundown of some of the most common pitfalls that you may come across when writing your own loops. Head on over to the next video to get started.
